entry.title: Sentiment analysis of Danish texts
entry.content:
The process of determining the emotional tone behind a series of words, used to gain an understanding of the the attitudes, opinions and emotions :weary: :expressionless: :smiley:

Sentiment analysis — also known as opnion mining — is as simple as assigning each word in a text a value based on the bias of the word, after which the overall tone is decided of the text.
This is especially useful for larger companies, who wish to gain an insight in their customers opionions regarding a certain topic. However, it could also be used as a tool for students analysing a Danish text, as it can help to quickly locate all positively or negatively charged words.



Although this so called wordlist-based approach has its flows — as it fails to identify sarcasm or passive aggresivness. It is better suited for formal language; However that said, it is still an execellent tool.

In this post we’ll be using the afinn package, as it supports the Danish language, although when it comes to English, textblob is the preffered choice.

Anyways! We start off by instantiating an instance of the Afinn object, followed by a namedtuple that is going to require 3 values, the polarity score of the word; the word itself; and the line number at which the word is located.

Getting the sentiment score of a text is straight forward. It is worth taking into account, that it’s a good idea to clean the text from “special characters” before analysing it, as it might cause some troubles in the analysis to for instance analyse a word such as: “extraordinary..?”.

Let’s test the functions on the following text:

A higher score is equal to a higher confidence in that the text is positive, meanwhile a lower score is equal to a higher confidence in that the text is conveying a negative sentiment. Now, let’s take a closer look at each word individually.

Not surprisingly, we do not have a lot of words affecting our total text score.
You can get the full code here.

Other examples of sentiment analysis.

  • Sentiment analysis of Danish politicians on Wikipedia
  • Sentiment analysis on Trump’s tweets
  • Exploring sentiment analysis as an application of text mining

Sentiment analysis of Danish texts was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on March 16, 2018.

entry.title: Twitter contest joiner bot
entry.content:
Automate the process of joining giveaway contests on Twitter :star2::star2::star2:

The inspiration for this post is drawn from this article.
A truly fun project I just had to try myself, so here it is; my own little version of the Twitter bot.

In order to use this bot, you will first have to sign up for the Twitter API. This should only take about 5 minutes. Get your keys, secrets, and token and fill out the required fields in the script.


Python 3.x          GitHub gist

You can experiment with the amount of time the bot should wait between each retweet/like/follow. But I wouldn’t advice you to decrease the sleep timer too much, since a too low sleep timer dramatically would increase the likely-hood of Twitter recognizing you as a spam bot; Which obviously is something you would not want to happen.

That said, you are free to do whatever you want with the code. Good luck!  :four_leaf_clover::four_leaf_clover:

Twitter contest joiner bot was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on March 09, 2018.

entry.title: VøBot
entry.content:
Færdiggør rentabilitetsanalyser på 40 sek. ! :hourglass_flowing_sand::hourglass: :ok_hand:

Dette software er udviklet til hhx studerende med fokus på at gøre det nemmere at arbejde med rentabiletsanalyser. Alt du skal gøre er at copy paste dine nøgletal ind i programmet, hvorefter VøBot skriver en rentabilitetsanalyse til et 12-tal! Som om det ikke er nok tillbyder VøBot en række ekstra features, som du kan læse mere om på VøBot’s hjemmeside:
:fire:www.voebot.tk:fire:

VøBot was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on March 05, 2018.

entry.title: Disable spotify ads
entry.content:
Spotify is coded in such a way that it will keep playing music, if it can’t gaing access to an ad. This script redirects all Spotify’s requests to the address 0.0.0.0 at which there is no ad resources located. That’s all there is it to. Enjoy the music! :musical_note::musical_note::musical_note:

Get the code

Instructions

  • Copy the code from the gist and paste it into a bat file.
    (A bat file is a file with the file extension .bat)
  • Run it

<code snippet>

@echo 
title Spotify-noad
:: BatchGotAdmin
:-------------------------------------
REM  --> Check for permissions
   IF "%PROCESSOR_ARCHITECTURE%" EQU "amd64" (
>nul 2>&1 "%SYSTEMROOT%\SysWOW64\cacls.exe" "%SYSTEMROOT%\SysWOW64\config\system"
) ELSE (
>nul 2>&1 "%SYSTEMROOT%\system32\cacls.exe" "%SYSTEMROOT%\system32\config\system"
)

Disable spotify ads was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on March 05, 2018.

entry.title: KingdomLikes Bot
entry.content:
Designed to automate the process of earning points on kingdomlikes. You can use the points to get like/followers/shares on a social media of your choice.

Get the code

Instructions :book:

  • Install Python 3.x :snake:
  • Edit config.json
  • Comment out the main function and uncomment the collect cookies function. Proceed to log onto your social medias account in the order the script tells you to.
  • Comment out the collect cookies function and uncomment the main function and run it.

Feeling generous ? :heart:

KingdomLikes Bot was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on March 05, 2018.

entry.title: Syntax Highlighting Post
entry.content:
Syntax highlighting is a feature that displays source code, in different colors and fonts according to the category of terms. This feature facilitates writing in a structured language such as a programming language or a markup language as both structures and syntax errors are visually distinct. Highlighting does not affect the meaning of the text itself; it is intended only for human readers.1

Rouge Code Blocks

To modify styling and highlight colors edit /_sass/_rouge.scss.

Standard Code Block

<nav class="pagination" role="navigation">
    {% if page.previous %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.previous.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.previous.title }}">Previous article</a>
    {% endif %}
    {% if page.next %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.next.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.next.title }}">Next article</a>
    {% endif %}
</nav><!-- /.pagination -->

  1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_highlighting ↩

Syntax Highlighting Post was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on December 01, 2016.

entry.title: Dark Post
entry.content:
This is a sample post to show the dark post theme. To use this dark theme, just add:

on your post. This theme adds a dark background with a white panel to show your content.

Dark Post was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on November 30, 2016.

entry.title: Post with a Background Image
entry.content:
Here be a sample post with a custom background image. To utilize this “feature” just add the following YAML to a post’s front matter.

This little bit of YAML makes the assumption that your background image asset is in the /images folder. If you place it somewhere else or are hotlinking from the web, just include the full http(s):// URL. Either way you should have a background image that is tiled.

If you want to set a background image for the entire site just add background: filename.png to your _config.yml and BOOM — background images on every page!

Background images from Subtle Patterns (Subtle Patterns) / CC BY-SA 3.0

Post with a Background Image was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on November 29, 2016.

entry.title: Sample Link Post
entry.content:
This theme supports link posts, made famous by John Gruber. To use, just add link: http://url-you-want-linked to the post’s YAML front matter and you’re done.

Sample Link Post was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on November 28, 2016.

entry.title: A Post with a Video
entry.content:
Video embeds are responsive and scale with the width of the main content block with the help of FitVids.

Adding YouTube video embeds causes errors when building your Jekyll site. To fix wrap the html within {::nomarkdown} tags. Example below:

A Post with a Video was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on November 27, 2016.

entry.title: A Post with Images
entry.content:
Here are some examples of what a post with images might look like. If you want to display two or three images next to each other responsively use figure with the appropriate class. Each instance of figure is auto-numbered and displayed in the caption.

Figures (for images or video)

One Up

One Center

Two Up

Apply the half class like so to display two images side by side that share the same caption.

And you’ll get something that looks like this:

Three Up

Apply the third class like so to display three images side by side that share the same caption.

And you’ll get something that looks like this:

Alternative way

Another way to achieve the same result is to include gallery Liquid template. In this case you don’t have to write any HTML tags – just copy a small block of code, adjust the parameters (see below) and fill the block with any number of links to images. You can mix relative and external links.

Here is the block you might want to use:

Parameters:

  • caption: Sets the caption under the gallery (see figcaption HTML tag above);
  • cols: Sets the number of columns of the gallery. Available values: [1..3].

It will look something like this:

A Post with Images was originally published by Sebastian Nielsen at Sebastian Nielsen's Blog on November 26, 2016.
